results.title: Live Updates: U.S. Market Rally Fades as China Trade Tensions Intensify
results.abstract: Stocks slipped in early trading, as investors assessed the economic impact of trade negotiations. The European Union paused its retaliatory tariffs and said it wanted to give talks with President Trump a chance.

results.title: After Trump’s Pause, E.U. Delays Retaliation to Allow Talks
results.abstract: The bloc had voted to impose retaliatory measures just before President Trump made his last-minute U-turn. It has now announced a postponement.

multimedia.caption: A steel plant in Duisburg, Germany, on Wednesday. Europe’s planned retaliation was in response to metal-sector tariffs, and those levies appeared to be still in place.
A steel plant in Duisburg, Germany, on Wednesday. Europe’s planned retaliation was in response to metal-sector tariffs, and those levies appeared to be still in place.
A steel plant in Duisburg, Germany, on Wednesday. Europe’s planned retaliation was in response to metal-sector tariffs, and those levies appeared to be still in place.

results.title: Death Toll in Dominican Republic Nightclub Hits 218
results.abstract: The number of dead in a roof collapse in Santo Domingo keeps rising. Officials have not said how many people were in the club at the time of the disaster.

multimedia.caption: Rescue workers at the Jet Set nightclub in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, on Wednesday, the day after its roof collapsed, killing over 200 people.
Rescue workers at the Jet Set nightclub in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, on Wednesday, the day after its roof collapsed, killing over 200 people.
Rescue workers at the Jet Set nightclub in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, on Wednesday, the day after its roof collapsed, killing over 200 people.

results.title: How a Ukrainian Teen Became a Suspected Foot Soldier for Russia
results.abstract: The teenager faces terrorism charges in an arson attack on an IKEA store in Lithuania. Investigators say it was part of a Russian sabotage campaign.
results.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus

multimedia.caption: The Ikea in Vilnius, Lithuania, where Daniil Bardadim is accused of planting an incendiary device.
The Ikea in Vilnius, Lithuania, where Daniil Bardadim is accused of planting an incendiary device.

results.title: Jaguar Paused Shipments to America. These Britons Blame Trump.
results.abstract: President Trump’s auto tariffs remain in place even after he paused many other levies. In Solihull, where Jaguar Land Rover employs 9,000 people and has suspended exports to the United States, residents are anxious.
results.byline: By Lizzie Dearden and Andrew Testa

results.title: Plunge in Oil Prices Threatens Russia’s Vast Spending on Ukraine War
results.abstract: The lower revenues, a result in part of President Trump’s trade war, could prove more damaging to the Russian economy than the penalties the United States and its allies have already imposed.

results.title: Asian Nations, Holding Few Cards, Seek Trade Talks With Trump
results.abstract: Southeast Asian leaders, their export-driven economies in peril, are trying to placate the president. “We may have to comply,” Thailand’s finance minister said.
results.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Zunaira Saieed

results.abstract: Ksenia Karelina, who was jailed in Russia over a one-time donation to a Ukrainian charity group, was released in exchange for Artur Petrov, a dual Russian-German citizen.

results.abstract: If sky-high U.S. tariffs hurt China’s exports, domestic spending will help make up for it, Beijing says. But shoppers were skittish even before the trade war.

results.title: Hundreds of Israeli Air Force Reservists Call for Halt to Gaza War
results.abstract: A letter signed by reservists and retired officers accused the government of endangering hostages held by Hamas, highlighting a growing divide over the handling of the war.

results.title: How Hamas and the U.S. Tried to Strike a Hostage Deal
results.abstract: Officials met Hamas three times, breaking with a policy against contacting a group the U.S. considers a terrorist organization. But Israeli opposition and shifting positions doomed the effort.
results.byline: By Adam Rasgon and Ronen Bergman

results.abstract: The strike on a home left other bodies buried under the rubble, according to the Gazan authorities. The Israeli military said it had been targeting a Hamas operative.

results.title: Kim Shin-jo, a Failed North Korean Assassin, Dies as a Pastor in the South
results.abstract: He famously said the mission of a hit squad sent by Pyongyang in 1968 was to “slit the throat” of the South Korean dictator Park Chung-hee. He was 82.

multimedia.caption: Kim Shin-jo, the North Korean commando sent with a hit squad in 1968 to kill the then dictator of South Korea was the only one captured.

results.title: Fridrik Olafsson, Grandmaster Who Led Iceland’s Rise in Chess, Dies at 90
results.abstract: At a time before his country became a chess powerhouse, he defeated four world champions, including Bobby Fischer and another in an unlikely turn of events.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Olafsson in 1976. He had taken a break from playing professionally until his passion for the game was reawakened in 1972 when a world championship tournament came to Iceland.

results.title: Michelle Obama Addresses Divorce Rumors and Public Absences
results.abstract: The former first lady said on a podcast that people “couldn’t even fathom that I was making a choice for myself, that they had to assume that my husband and I are divorcing.”

results.title: Trump Team Divided Over Future of U.S. Counterterrorism Operations in Somalia
results.abstract: Some State Department officials have proposed closing the embassy in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, as a precaution after recent gains by Al Shabab militants.

results.abstract: U.S. officials said Ronald Johnson’s actions during his time as ambassador to El Salvador seemed less aligned with U.S. interests and more focused on protecting the country’s president.

results.title: An Advance in Brain Research That Was Once Considered Impossible
results.abstract: Scientists achieved “a milestone” by charting the activity and structure of 200,000 cells in a mouse brain and their 523 million connections.

results.title: Britain Lost Out on Euro Disney. Now It’s Getting a Universal Theme Park.
results.abstract: A yet-to-be-named Universal Studios theme park will be the country’s largest tourist attraction when it opens in 2031. But studio executives have not yet said which characters will be featured.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, center, with renderings of the proposed Universal Studios theme park.
Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, center, with renderings of the proposed Universal Studios theme park.

results.title: Coalition Deal in Germany Clears Way for Friedrich Merz to Become Chancellor
results.abstract: The agreement was concluded relatively quickly but still took about six and half weeks, during which the country had been virtually rudderless at a critical moment for Europe.

multimedia.caption: Friedrich Merz had been under pressure to get a coalition government moving.

results.title: Congo Repatriates 3 Americans Sentenced to Death Over Failed Coup
results.abstract: The men recently had their sentences commuted to life imprisonment for their role in an attempted coup last May in the central African nation.

results.title: Netanyahu Sticks by Trump’s Brazen Proposal for Gazans to Leave
results.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said his government was serious about “voluntary” migration, after an Oval Office meeting where President Trump appeared to have lost interest.

multimedia.caption: Asked on Monday about Gaza emigration, President Trump said it was “a concept that I had,” and passed the question to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

results.title: Paddington Returns to His Bench. Order Is Restored.
results.abstract: Two men vandalized a statue of England’s beloved storybook bear last month. On Wednesday, he was returned to his bench in the town of Newbury — with a marmalade sandwich, of course.

multimedia.caption: Paddington Bear is back in Newbury, England, enjoying a marmalade sandwich and the sunny weather.
Paddington Bear is back in Newbury, England, enjoying a marmalade sandwich and the sunny weather.

results.title: A Dominican Club That Drew Bold-Face Names Became a Graveyard in a Flash
results.abstract: The scene at the Jet Set nightclub in Santo Domingo, where the roof collapsed early Tuesday killing at least 218, was increasingly grim as bodies but no more survivors were recovered.

multimedia.caption: Rescue teams working at the Jet Set nightclub a day after the collapse of its roof in Santo Domingo on Wednesday.

results.title: India’s Millions of New Investors Are Reeling From Tariff Turmoil
results.abstract: Legions of ordinary Indians have gone into stock trading, lured by easy online access and a market boom. Now many of them are getting a rude shock.
results.byline: By Anupreeta Das, Pragati K.B. and Hari Kumar

multimedia.caption: The Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai on Monday, when Indian stocks lost about $170 billion in value.
The Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai on Monday, when Indian stocks lost about $170 billion in value.

results.title: Zelensky Doubles Down on Claim That Many Chinese Are Fighting for Russia
results.abstract: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said more than 150 Chinese men were fighting for Russia in Ukraine, hours after China dismissed claims that many of its citizens were involved in the war.
results.byline: By Berry Wang, Cassandra Vinograd and Constant Méheut

multimedia.caption: Lin Jian, a spokesman for China’s foreign ministry, disputed a Ukrainian claim that many Chinese volunteers were fighting for Russia in Ukraine, on Wednesday in Beijing.
Lin Jian, a spokesman for China’s foreign ministry, disputed a Ukrainian claim that many Chinese volunteers were fighting for Russia in Ukraine, on Wednesday in Beijing.

results.title: U.S. Bond Sell-Off Is Another Worrisome Echo of the Liz Truss Fiasco
results.abstract: Yields on U.S. Treasuries rose Wednesday as investors sold government bonds, usually a haven. In Britain, a sustained version of that trend in 2022 led to a prime minister’s downfall.

multimedia.caption: Former British Prime Minister Liz Truss triggered market turmoil in 2022 after she proposed sweeping tax cuts. She was forced to step down after 44 days in office.
Former British Prime Minister Liz Truss triggered market turmoil in 2022 after she proposed sweeping tax cuts. She was forced to step down after 44 days in office.

results.title: For U.S. and China, a Risky Game of Chicken With No Off-Ramp in Sight
results.abstract: China’s latest move: an additional 50 percent tariff on U.S. goods. Neither side wants to look weak by backing down, but a collapse of their trade ties could have profound consequences.
results.byline: By David Pierson and Berry Wang
org_facet: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
